case_name: M/s. Bhikusa Yamasa Kahatriya and M/s. Bastiram Narayandas v. State of Bombay

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 546 of 1961 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 546 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated June 27 and 30, 1958 and November 28, 1958 of Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 67 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated June 27 and 30, 1958 and November 28, 1958, of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 67 of 1958.

facts.text: Ms. Bhikusa Yamasa Kshatriya and Ms. Bastiram Narayandas are owners of bidi factories at Sangamner in Ahmednagar District.

anchor.surface_text: M s. Bhikusa Yamasa Kahatriya and M s. Bastiram Narayandas  owners of bidi factories at Sangamner in the District of Ahmednagar  hereinafter referred to

facts.text: Appellants moved Bombay High Court under Article 226 for writ declaring s.3(3)(iv) of Minimum Wages Act, 1948 and Notification dated April 19, 1955 ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: moved the High Court of judicature at Bombay under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying for a writ or direction declaring s. 3 3  iv  of the Minimum Wages Act, 1948,  XI of 1948

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed the petition on June 27/30 and November 28, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the petition, for in their view, s. 3 3  iv  of the Minimum Wages Act and the Notification dated April 19, 1955, fixing minimum rates

facts.text: Appeal preferred with certificate under Art. 133(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: Against the order, with certificate of fitness granted by the High Court under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution, this appeal is preferred by the appellants.

facts.text: Minimum Wages Act, 1948 enacted by Parliament to fix minimum rates in certain employments.

anchor.surface_text: The Minimum Wages Act, 1948, was enacted by the Parliament to provide for fixing minimum rates of wages in certain employments.

facts.text: Employment in tobacco including bidi-making manufactory in Part I of Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: Employment in any tobacco  including bidi-making  manufactory is one of the items in Part I of the Schedule to the Act.

facts.text: Government of Bombay by Resolution dated February 27, 1951 appointed Committee under s.5.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers companyferred by s. 5 the Government of Bombay by Resolution dated February 27, 1951, appointed a Committee to hold enquiry

facts.text: Committee consisted of three employers representatives, equal number of employees representatives and independent chairman.

anchor.surface_text: The Committee companysisted of three employers representatives, an equal number of employees representatives and an independent chairman.

facts.text: On July 3, 1952, Government appointed Committee under s.6 for revision of zoning and rates.

anchor.surface_text: On July 3, 1952, the Government of Bombay appointed, in exercise of powers companyferred under s. 6, a Committee to assist it in companysidering

facts.text: Advisory Board constituted by Resolution dated October 3, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: An Advisory Board was also companystituted by Resolution dated October 3, 1953.

facts.text: Notification operative from March 31, 1952 fixing minimum rates in Zones I to IV, Zone III includes Ahmednagar, Rs. 2/- per 1000 bidis without leaves.

anchor.surface_text: A numberification operative from March 31, 1952, was thereafter issued ... Districts of Thana, Ahmednagar, ... In Zone III in the Bidi making industry for making 1000 bidis a minimum rate of Rs. 2/-  without leaves  was prescribed.

facts.text: Notification dated June 30, 1955 under s.26(2) exempted bidi makers in Sangamner and Akola for 3 months from July 1, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: By Notification dated June 30, 1955, issued under s. 26 2  the Government of Bombay directed that for a period of three months with effect from July 1, 1955,

facts.text: Exemption extended till end of December 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This exemption was extended from time to time, till the end of December 1956,

facts.text: Notification dated August 22, 1956 cancelled exemption effective September 1, 1956 for Sangamner and Akola.

anchor.surface_text: but by Notification dated August 22, 1956, the Government of Bombay cancelled the exemption with effect from September 1, 1956, in respect of Sangamner and Akola

facts.text: Notification dated April 19, 1955 revised minimum rates to Rs. 2/2/- per 1000 bidis for Sangamner and Akola.

anchor.surface_text: by Notification dated April 19, 1955, the Government of Bombay after companysidering the report of the Advisory Committee ... fixed ... a minimum rate of Rs. 2/2/- for making 1000 bidis.

facts.text: After cancellation of exemption, workers demanded wages at revised rates.

anchor.surface_text: After the exemption granted under s. 26 2  was cancelled workers employed in the Bidi industry in Sangamner and Akola ... demanded wages at the revised rates.

facts.text: Employers failed to pay, workers filed applications under s.20 to Regional authority.

anchor.surface_text: The employers having failed to satisfy their demands, applications were preferred by the workers under s. 20 of the Minimum Wages Act to the Regional authority

facts.text: Regional authority by order dated November 6, 1957 held workers entitled to wages from January 1, 1957 at rates in April 19, 1955 notification.

anchor.surface_text: By order dated November 6, 1957, the authority under the Minimum Wages Act rejected the companytentions raised by the employers and held that the workers were entitled to wages, at the rates fixed ... as from January 1, 1957,

facts.text: Appellants contended s.3(3)(iv) confers arbitrary power, discriminatory.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal companynsel for the appellants companytends -  1  that s. 3 3  iv  of the Minimum Wages Act, 1948 companyfers arbitrary and uncontrolled power

facts.text: Appellants contended Notification April 19, 1955 discriminatory.

anchor.surface_text: 2  that the Notification dated April 19, 1955, is discriminatory and violates the fundamental right of equality

facts.text: Appellants contended ss.5,6,7,9 contravened as no representatives of bidi employers in Advisory Board.

anchor.surface_text: 3  that ss. 5, 6, 7 and 9 were companytravened because the Committees were number validly companys- tituted there being in the Advisory Board numberrepresentatives of employers in the Bidi industry,

facts.text: Supreme Court held s.3(3)(iv) does not contravene Art.19(1)(g) or Art.14.

anchor.surface_text: On a careful examination ... we hold that s. 3 3  iv  does number companytravene Art. 19 1  f  of the Constitution number does it infringe the equal pro- tection clause of the Constitution

facts.text: Supreme Court held Notification April 19, 1955 does not violate Art.14.

anchor.surface_text: we also hold that the Notification dated April 19, 1,955 did number violate Art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court held constitution of Committees and Advisory Board did not contravene statutory provisions.

anchor.surface_text: We are further of the view that the companystitution of the Committees and the Advisory Board did number companytravene the statutory provisions in that behalf prescribed by the Legislature.

facts.text: Nasik Bidi manufacturers made representations against revised rates.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that representations were made by the Nasik Bidi manufacturers who were bracketed with the Bidi manufacturers of Sangamner and Akola

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shah J. on October 10, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. October, 10. The judgment of the Court, was delivered by SHAH, J.-.

issues.text: Whether s.3(3)(iv) of the Minimum Wages Act, 1948 confers arbitrary and uncontrolled power upon the State Government to fix different minimum rates of wages for different localities, enabling discrimination contrary to the equal protection clause of the Constitution (Art.14) and imposing unreasonable restrictions on the right to carry on business under Art.19(1)(f)?

anchor.surface_text: 1 that s. 3 3 iv of the Minimum Wages Act, 1948 confers arbitrary and uncontrolled power upon the State Government to fix rates of minimum wages in respect of certain localities, and thereby enables the Government to discriminate contrary to the equal protection clause of the Constitution against the employers carrying on their business in those localities, and on that account the exercise of the power so conferred also amounts to imposing unreasonable restrictions upon their right to carry on their business under Art. 19 1 f of the Constitution

issues.text: Whether the Notification dated April 19, 1955 is discriminatory and violates the fundamental right of equality before law guaranteed by the Constitution (Art.14)?

anchor.surface_text: 2 that the Notification dated April 19, 1955, is discriminatory and violates the fundamental right of equality before law guaranteed by the Constitution

issues.text: Whether ss.5, 6, 7 and 9 of the Minimum Wages Act were contravened because the Committees were not validly constituted (no representatives of employers in the Bidi industry in the Advisory Board), rendering the revision of minimum wages under the Notification dated April 19, 1955 unlawful?

anchor.surface_text: 3 that ss. 5, 6, 7 and 9 were contravened because the Committees were not validly constituted there being in the Advisory Board no representatives of employers in the Bidi industry, and therefore there was no lawful revision of minimum wages under the Notification dated April 19, 1955.

issues.text: Whether s.3(3)(iv) and the Notification dated April 19, 1955 are ultra vires, void and illegal as infringing the guarantee of equal protection of the laws (Art.14) and affecting the rights to carry on lawful business?

The State of Ajmer  1 . Mukherjea, J., speaking for the Court in that case observed that having regard to the scheme of the Act

anchor.surface_text: In a recent judgment of this Court in U. Unichoyi v. The State of Kerala 2  it was observed that what the Minimum Wages Act purports to achieve is to prevent exploitation of labour and for that purpose authorises the appropriate Government to take steps to prescribe minimum rates of wages in the scheduled industries.

anchor.surface_text: On a careful examination of the various provisions of the Act and the machinery set up thereby we hold that s. 3 3  iv  does number companytravene Art. 19 1  f  of the Constitution number does it infringe the equal pro- tection clause of the Constitution

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act's object to prevent exploitation provides policy guidance; ss.4-9 prescribe procedures and machinery ensuring no arbitrary power; reasonable classification permitted under Art.14 with intelligible differentia and rational nexus; follows precedents like Bijay Cotton Mills

holdings.text: The Notification dated April 19, 1955 did not violate Art. 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: we also hold that the Notification dated April 19, 1,955 did number violate Art. 14 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification based on full enquiry by committees, consideration of representations, and local conditions showing intelligent differentia (varying economic factors) with rational nexus to preventing exploitation

holdings.text: The constitution of the Committees and the Advisory Board did not contravene the statutory provisions

anchor.surface_text: We are further of the view that the companystitution of the Committees and the Advisory Board did number companytravene the statutory provisions in that behalf prescribed by the Legislature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Committees and boards constituted per s.9 with equal employer/employee reps + independents; s.7 Advisory Board for coordination/general advice, not requiring industry-specific reps; detailed investigation by s.5/6 committees

precedents.cited_proposition: Section 3 of the Minimum Wages Act does not infringe Art. 19(1)(f) as the restraints on freedom of contract are reasonable given the scheme and purpose of the Act to secure minimum wages and protect against exploitation
